ocr.sentence: studies have found the secrets of the starres the bookes that I have made of them, doe serve for presi-dents to our greatest doctors, so excellent hath my judgment beene therein.
ocr.region: OF FRYER BACON. 249 my studies have found the secrets of the starres the bookes that I have made of them, doe serve for presi dents to our greatest doctors, so excellent hath my judgment beene therein. I Hkewisehave found out the secrets of trees, plants and stones, with their ' several uses yet aU this knowledge of mine I esteeme so lightly, that I wish that I were ignorant, and knew nothing for the knowledge of these things, as I have truly found serveth not to better a man in goodnesse, but onely to make him proud and thinke too well of himselfe. What hath all my knowledge of natures secrets gained me ? Onely this, the losse of a better knowledge, the losse of divine studies, which makes the immortaU part of man his soule blessed. I have found, that my knowledge has beene. a heavy burden, and has kept downe my good thoughts but I will remove the cause, which are these bookes which I doe purpose here before you all to burne. They all intreated him to spare the bookes, because in them there were those things that after-ages might receive great benefit by. He would not hearken unto them, but threw them all into the fire, and in that flame burnt the greatest learning in the world. Then did he dispose of aH his goods some part he gave to poor schollers, and some he gave to other poore folkes nothing left he for him selfe then caused he to be made in the church-waU a cell, where he locked himselfe in, and there remained tiU his death. His time hee spent in prayer, medita tion, and such divine exercises, and did seeke by aU

prediction.region: means to recover the grace of God, which he had lost by his vicious life. This is the manner how one of the most famous and vertuous men of the world, the best and most excellent theologian of this our age, lost all his worldly possessions, was excommunicated, and in his old age locked himselfe in a churche-wall and lived there, as did Simeon the holy Evangelist, and others like unto him, after the example of Christ. It is well to observe these things, that we may not lose our grace, and be made as he was, as many have been, who in the midst of their prosperity have lost their grace by reason of their negligence. But for our recreation, and for the profit of the people, which we have promised to entertain this day, it will be expedient, to declare unto you the manner how he who lost all his worldly riches and honour, by the help of a few bookes, which was his destruction, became famous by his labours, which was his redemption. The manner of his life he did observe after the example of the ancients, as well in all his exercises as in his outward behaviour and behaviour in his body, in all the manner of his life, he was not wanting in any thing, wherein it may be said that he was a man of all seasons. He was always ready for the doing of almesdeeds, and gave the same often without the need of any one to spie of it, and his hand was always stretched forth, both to help the poore and to doe other works of charitie; he would take any occasion to give in charity, and was ever mindful to be ready to do the like. He kept himselfe humble and lowly, as one that did not know himselfe, and as a true disciple of Christ. As

This is the manner how one of the most famous and vertuous men of the world, the best and most excellent theologian of this our age, lost all his worldly possessions, was excommunicated, and in his old age locked himselfe in a churche-wall and lived there, as did Simeon the holy Evangelist, and others like unto him, after the example of Christ. It is well to observe these things, that we may not lose our grace, and be made as he was, as many have been, who in the midst of their prosperity have lost their grace by reason of their negligence. But for our recreation, and for the profit of the people, which we have promised to entertain this day, it will be expedient, to declare unto you the manner how he who lost all his worldly riches and honour, by the help of a few bookes, which was his destruction, became famous by his labours, which was his redemption. The manner of his life he did observe after the example of the ancients, as well in all his exercises as in his outward behaviour and behaviour in his body, in all the manner of his life, he was not wanting in any thing, wherein it may be said that he was a man of all seasons. He was always ready for the doing of almesdeeds, and gave the same often without the need of any one to spie of it, and his hand was always stretched forth, both to help the poore and to doe other works of charitie; he would take any occasion to give in charity, and was ever mindful to be ready to do the like. ocr.sentence: Mais celui-ci avait rflchi, et cette fois son avis fut tout oppos.
ocr.region: 290 CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. XXXV Cette crise fut plus longue que ceile qui avait prcd, et il y eut un moment o le mdecin dsespra du succs. Ce n'tait plus l'action du poison qui tait  craindre, mais l'ef-fet de cette secousse morale sur une organisation dj pro-fondment atteinte. Ludovic s'accusait et se dsesprait, il rejetait sur lui la responsabilit de cette rechute, et parlait de suivre la jeune fille si elle n'en rchappait pas. Il demandait pardon au doc-teur de n'avoir pas mieux suivi ses conseils et offrait de quitter la chambre afin de ne pas compromettre de nouveau les effets de son traitement. Mais celui-ci avait rflchi, et cette fois son avis fut tout oppos. - Non, lui dit-il, restez. - Mais si je commets encore quelque imprudence ? - Restez, vous dis-je, le mal est fait. Vtre prsence a amen une crise, votre absence en amnerait une auire, plus fcheuse encore. Je ne connaissais pas cette enfant c'est une tte de fer. Il faut que vous soyez l, quand elle reprendra ses sens. Restez. - J'obis alors. - Et que le ciel vous inspire, Ludovic, quand le moment sera venu. Cette jeune fille a au coeur une plaie dont je ne puis la gurir et que la Facult en corps ne gurirait pas c'est le dgot de la vie. Tchez d'en venir  bout et j'incli-nerai ma science devant la vtre. L'aimez-vous ? - Si je l'aime 1 Vous me demandez si je l'aime! Ne le voyez-vous pas ? - Eh bien 1 alors, il y a quelque chance pour que vous russissiez. Mais, ou je me trompe fort, ou ce sera une cure difficile. ocr.sentence: -Et que le ciel vous inspire, Ludovic, quand le moment sera venu.
ocr.region: 290 CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. XXXV Cette crise fut plus longue que ceile qui avait prcd, et il y eut un moment o le mdecin dsespra du succs. Ce n'tait plus l'action du poison qui tait  craindre, mais l'ef-fet de cette secousse morale sur une organisation dj pro-fondment atteinte. Ludovic s'accusait et se dsesprait, il rejetait sur lui la responsabilit de cette rechute, et parlait de suivre la jeune fille si elle n'en rchappait pas. Il demandait pardon au doc-teur de n'avoir pas mieux suivi ses conseils et offrait de quitter la chambre afin de ne pas compromettre de nouveau les effets de son traitement. Mais celui-ci avait rflchi, et cette fois son avis fut tout oppos. - Non, lui dit-il, restez. - Mais si je commets encore quelque imprudence ? - Restez, vous dis-je, le mal est fait. Vtre prsence a amen une crise, votre absence en amnerait une auire, plus fcheuse encore. Je ne connaissais pas cette enfant c'est une tte de fer. Il faut que vous soyez l, quand elle reprendra ses sens. Restez. - J'obis alors. - Et que le ciel vous inspire, Ludovic, quand le moment sera venu. Cette jeune fille a au coeur une plaie dont je ne puis la gurir et que la Facult en corps ne gurirait pas c'est le dgot de la vie. Tchez d'en venir  bout et j'incli-nerai ma science devant la vtre. L'aimez-vous ? - Si je l'aime 1 Vous me demandez si je l'aime! Ne le voyez-vous pas ? - Eh bien 1 alors, il y a quelque chance pour que vous russissiez. Mais, ou je me trompe fort, ou ce sera une cure difficile. Cet entretien avait lieu  voix si basse, que rien n'en pou-vait parvenir aux oreilles de Marguerite, et, pourtant, il se fit chez elle un mouvement singulier. ocr.region: 290 CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. XXXV Cette crise fut plus longue que ceile qui avait prcd, et il y eut un moment o le mdecin dsespra du succs. ocr.sentence: matter the king was very glad hereof, and caused the combatants to be brought before him, to whom he said gentlemen, to save the blood of you all, I have found a way, and yet the controversie shall be ended that is now amongst you Are you contented to stand to his iudg-ment that I shall appoint they all answered, that they were.
ocr.region: OF FRYER BACON. 221 the matter the kingwas very glad hereof,and caused the combatants to be brought before him, to whom he said gentlemen, to save the blood of you all, I have found a way, and yet the controversie shall be ended that is now amongst you Are you contented to stand to his iudg ment that I shaU appoint they all answered, that they were. Then were they bid to returne three days after. In that time Fryer Bacon had caused the body of their deceased father to be taken out of the ground, and brought to the court the body hee did cause to be bound to a stake, naked to the middle upwards and Hkewise prepared three bowes and shafts for the three brethren all these kept hee secretly. The third day being come, came these three brethren, to whom Fryer Bacon in the presence of the king gave the three bowes and shafts, saying, be not offended at what I have done, there is no other way but this to judge your cause See here is the body of your dead father, shoot at him, for he that cometh nearest to his heart, shad have aU the lands and goods. The two eldest prepared themselves, and shot at him, and stucke their arrowes in his breast. Then bid they the youngest to shoot but he refused it, saying, I will rather loose aU, then wound that body that I so loved living Had you ever had but halfe that love in you to him that I have, you would rather have had your own bodies mangled, than to suffer his lifelesse corps thus to be used nay, you doe not onely suffer it, but you are the actors of this act of shame and speaking this, he wept.

prediction.region: Afterwards I find him a very wise lawgiver and politician. He wrote an immortal book "The History of King Richard the Second." There are several editions of it in English, and some excellent translations into the other languages of Europe. He died in the year 1626. He was one of those great poets who have no equal, and who are always the glory and ornament of a nation. He has been called " the divine Milton." His character is a noble one. We have no idea of that dignity, that grandeur, that loftiness which pervades his whole poems, unless we know that he is a man to whom all these qualities are a second nature, and with whom they seem a necessity of his very existence. He was born in the year 1608. He was but ten years old when his mother died. In 1633 he left Cambridge, and he has since been engaged in public affairs, either as a secretary, or an agent, or as a member of the privy council. He has filled every department of the government, with a degree of wisdom and ability, which is the wonder and admiration of all his country men. In all his writings there is a greatness of soul, a moral courage, an elevation of sentiment, a lofty elevation of mind, which is not to be found in any other writings. When he was but thirteen years of age, and but just entered on life, he composed "On his first Sonnet," the first four lines of which have been so often quoted, and so frequently admired that I cannot but mention them to you. "From the first moment that I saw, Thy lively Eyes, my soul was thrall'd; And I have lov'd Thee since I first was seene. Thy Eyes, since that I first did see them, Have bl

ocr.sentence: Then were they bid to returne three days after.
ocr.region: OF FRYER BACON. 221 the matter the kingwas very glad hereof,and caused the combatants to be brought before him, to whom he said gentlemen, to save the blood of you all, I have found a way, and yet the controversie shall be ended that is now amongst you Are you contented to stand to his iudg ment that I shaU appoint they all answered, that they were. Then were they bid to returne three days after. In that time Fryer Bacon had caused the body of their deceased father to be taken out of the ground, and brought to the court the body hee did cause to be bound to a stake, naked to the middle upwards and Hkewise prepared three bowes and shafts for the three brethren all these kept hee secretly. The third day being come, came these three brethren, to whom Fryer Bacon in the presence of the king gave the three bowes and shafts, saying, be not offended at what I have done, there is no other way but this to judge your cause See here is the body of your dead father, shoot at him, for he that cometh nearest to his heart, shad have aU the lands and goods. The two eldest prepared themselves, and shot at him, and stucke their arrowes in his breast. Then bid they the youngest to shoot but he refused it, saying, I will rather loose aU, then wound that body that I so loved living Had you ever had but halfe that love in you to him that I have, you would rather have had your own bodies mangled, than to suffer his lifelesse corps thus to be used nay, you doe not onely suffer it, but you are the actors of this act of shame and speaking this, he wept.

ocr.sentence: his master had great marvaile then they sate downe to breakfast, which being ended they went home, and did such thinges as were there to bee done when his dame sawe that he had so soone ended his busines, she thought that he was a profitable servant, and said little but let him alone.
ocr.region: OF FRIER RUSH. 295 whereat his master had great marvade then they sate downe to breakfast, which being ended they went home, and did such thinges as were there to bee done when his dame sawe that he had so soone ended his busines, she thought that he was a profitable servant, and said Httle but let him alone. In the evening Rush de maunded of his master what hee should doe the next morrow ? his master appointed him twice so much as hee did the day before, which Rush refused not, but got up earely in the morning, and went to the field, and about his worke so soone as his master was ready, he tooke his man's breakfast and came to the field, thinking to helpe Rush but he was no sooner come from his house but the Priest came to see his wife, and presently shee made ready some good meate for them to be merry withall, and whyle it was a dressing, they sate sporting together, who had beene there should have seene many loving touches. And when the goodman came to the field, he found that Rush had done aU that which he appointed, whereof he had great marvade then they sate dovroe to breakfast, and as they sate together, Rush beheld his master's shoone, and perceived that for fault of greasing they were very hard then said Rush to his master, why are not your shooes better greased ? I marvade that you can goe in them, they be so hard, have you no more at home ? Ves, said his master, I have another payre lying under a great chest at home in my chamber. Then said Rush I wdl goe home and grease them that you may put them on to-morrow and
groundtruth.sentence: OF FRIER RUSH. 295 whereat his master had great marvade then they sate downe to breakfast, which being ended they went home, and did such thinges as were there to bee done when his dame sawe that he had so soone ended his busines, she thought that he was a profitable servant, and said Httle but let him alone.

In the evening Rush de-maunded of his master what hee should doe the next morrow ? his master appointed him twice so much as hee did the day before, which Rush refused not. but got up earely in the morning, and went to the field, and about his worke so soone as his master was ready, he tooke his man's breakfast and came to the field, thinking to helpe Rush but he was no sooner come from his house but the Priest came to see his wife, and presently shee made ready some good meate for them to be merry withall, and whyle it was a dressing, they sate sporting together, who had beene there should have seene many loving touches. And when the goodman came to the field, he found that Rush had done all that which he appointed, whereof he had great marvaile then they sate downe to breakfast, and as they sate together, Rush beheld his master's shoone, and perceived that for fault of greasing they were very hard then said Rush to his master, why are not your shooes better greased ? I marvaile that you can goe in them, they be so hard, have you no more at home ? Yes, said his master, I have another payre lying under a great chest at home in my chamber. Then said Rush I will goe home and grease them that you may put them on to-morrow and

prediction.region:
then the fellow said to his master, if I doe you this service I pray you that you will give me my payre. Then the goodman answered, by my faith, my friend Rush, I will doe you that good. Then the goodman went to the chest, and brought out the shoone, and went to his chamber, and when Rush came there, he saw his master so busie with his shoone that he took him by the sleeue, and said, what mean you ? I pray you stay there while I grease the shoone, you know that I have done you a great service, I pray you stay. His master answered, by my faith, my friend Rush, I will not stay, but goe to the field to worke, and while hee was greasing them, hee saw Rush come forth from the chamber, and hee tooke the shoone that Rush had laied aside, and went his way, and he that was sent for the shoone was never heard of more.
Then said Rush, now shall I see if I am in a right place or no, and so he made himselve very merry with the shoone, and when his master came to the field he asked him, where was his other shoone that he was to grease? why, replied the master, I found them in the chest, and when he had greased them hee saw them no more. Then said Rush, you deceivest me. How did you find them in the chest ? your wife saw mee take them out of the chest. Then Rush said, she lyeth. ocr.sentence: space of seaven yeares, and did right well, and every man had him in love and favour.
ocr.region: OF FRIER RUSH. 271 the space of seaven yeares, and did right well, and every man bad him in love and favour. Then it fortuned upon a day the Priour and his brethren were assembled together in a generaU counsaile, and as they stood talking together, the Priour remembered Rush, and anon he said unto his brethren Friends we have here Rush which is our maister Cooke in our kitchin, and be is an olde servant, and much diligent and true service he hath done to us, and he hath continued among us longer then any servant that ever wee had wherefore me thinke it reason, that hee were promoted into some other office, and made a brother among us. Then all the whole Covent with one voice said they were content it should so be. So the Priour sent for Rush, and when he was come before him and aU bis brethren, the Priour said, Rush it is so, thou hast beene here a long season, and we have found thee hitherto a true and diligent servant, wherefore wee wdl that thou be promoted, and take upon thee an habite as we have, and to become a brother among us. Rush answered and said my Maisters I thanke you aU, and then the Priour gave Rush an habite, and put it on his backe, and so Rush became a brother in the place, neverthelesse he kept his office stiU. How Frier Rush made Truncheons for the Friers to fight withaU. When Rush had on the habite of a Frier, and was a brother in the place, he had more vacation dayes

prediction.region: &c. The above text is copied from an old MS. in the College Library. " Frier Rush's dayes" is the dayes when Friers and other religious orders kept their Vacation from labour. The MS. is so imperfect, that this part of the story cannot be perfectly known, but what it seems to intimate is, that on those days the Friers used to fight with Rush's truncheons. " How Rush died of the poxe" is copied in like manner. Frier Rush died at the time of the great pestilence in 1349, and this passage seems to refer to the custom of the Friers going to bury the dead of the pestilence. We give a facsimile of a part of the MS. underneath this. There are also several notes, as follows: " A mss of the year 1450. In the college library at Oxford. There are alsochestrae to bee sung, and the music noted and printed in 1529 by T. Godfrey, B.D. at Cambrige. "In the same college Library, a Book entitled The Concord of the two Bookees of Maister Wickliffe and the Booke of Maister John Wycliffe, with the notes thereof, as they have beene extorted out of the Bookees." "A mss. called The Lives of the Fryers of the house of God, of this place, at Oxon. by Frier Adam, B.D. at Oxon. Anno Dom. 1516. ocr.region: OF FRIER RUSH. 271 the space of seaven yeares, and did right well, and every man bad him in love and favour. Then it fortuned upon a day the Priour and his brethren were assembled together in a generaU counsaile, and as they stood talking together, the Priour remembered Rush, and anon he said unto his brethren Friends we have here Rush which is our maister Cooke in our kitchin, and be is an olde servant, and much diligent and true service he hath done to us, and he hath continued among us longer then any servant that ever wee had wherefore me thinke it reason, that hee were promoted into some other office, and made a brother among us. Then all the whole Covent with one voice said they were content it should so be. So the Priour sent for Rush, and when he was come before him and aU bis brethren, the Priour said, Rush it is so, thou hast beene here a long season, and we have found thee hitherto a true and diligent servant, wherefore wee wdl that thou be promoted, and take upon thee an habite as we have, and to become a brother among us. Rush answered and said my Maisters I thanke you aU, and then the Priour gave Rush an habite, and put it on his backe, and so Rush became a brother in the place, neverthelesse he kept his office stiU. How Frier Rush made Truncheons for the Friers to fight withaU. When Rush had on the habite of a Frier, and was a brother in the place, he had more vacation dayes

prediction.region: &c. The above text is copied from an old MS. in the College Library. " Frier Rush's dayes" is the dayes when Friers and other religious orders kept their Vacation from labour. The MS. is so imperfect, that this part of the story cannot be perfectly known, but what it seems to intimate is, that on those days the Friers used to fight with Rush's truncheons. " How Rush died of the poxe" is copied in like manner. Frier Rush died at the time of the great pestilence in 1349, and this passage seems to refer to the custom of the Friers going to bury the dead of the pestilence. We give a facsimile of a part of the MS. underneath this. There are also several notes, as follows: " A mss of the year 1450. In the college library at Oxford. There are alsochestrae to bee sung, and the music noted and printed in 1529 by T. Godfrey, B.D. at Cambrige. "In the same college Library, a Book entitled The Concord of the two Bookees of Maister Wickliffe and the Booke of Maister John Wycliffe, with the notes thereof, as they have beene extorted out of the Bookees." "A mss. called The Lives of the Fryers of the house of God, of this place, at Oxon. by Frier Adam, B.D. at Oxon. Anno Dom. 1516. "A mss. of the year 1637. in the College Library at Oxon. called The Annals of Oxford. It begins with the death of

ocr.sentence: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE.
ocr.region: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. 251 comme une exception parmi le commun des hommes, et que vous tiez ce qu'ils sont tous, perfides et trompeurs  l'occasion. Quand je relevai la tte, l'obscurit la plus complte salait faite dans votre logement, et une lueur d'espoir tra-, versa mon esprit. Point de doute vous alliez venir, vous alliez paratre. Nulle puissance humaine ne m'et contrainte  croire que vous passeriez la journe sans me voir et sans tenir la promesse que vous m'aviez faite. Vous tiez-donc en. chemin j'en tais convaincue comme d'un article de foi. En - effet, la sonnette retentit quelqu'un tait l. - Ab 1 enfin, m'criai-je, le voici Dieu soit lou ! Je courus vers la porte et ouvris. C'tait Melchior. XXVI Je ne chercherai pas, Ludovic,  vous raconter ce que j'prouvai  la vue de cet homme. Ce fut un sentiment si bizarre, si ml, si excessif qu'il me serait impossible de l'analyser. Ce qui y dominait, c'tait la colre vis--vis de vous, et vis--vis de lui de la rpugnance. Pourquoi tait-il l et non pas vous? A quel titre se prsentait-il 1 Etait-ce de votre part? Que pouvait-il avoir  me dire? A -tout. prendre, si c'tait votre messager, vous aviez eu, en le choisissant, la main singulirement malheureuse. Il faut que ma physionomie ait exprim, en partie du moins, les sentiments qui m'agitaient, ou bien que Melchior et prpar, en habile acteur, les nuances de son rle. Tou-jours est-il qu'il s'en tira  son avantage et se conduisit de manire  me dsarmer. Dans l'opinion que je m'en tais forme, cet homme devait porter en tout lieu et en toute cir-constance les airs impertinents qui lui taient habituels et dont j'avais eu tant  souffrir. Je me figurais qu'il allait le prendre sur le mme pied et se mettre  l'aise chez moi comme il s'y

prediction.region: ettait chez lui-mme. Je l'eus jusqu' la fin de ma visite, qu'il n'en eut rien fait. Il me parut modeste, grave et convenable en tout. Nous fmes bien gentils l'un  l'gard de l'autre, et j'eus beaucoup  me louer de son air et de sa conduite. Aprs avoir parl du logement que j'avais lou et de la situation o vous et Melchior en tiez pour l'instant, nous prmes cong l'un de l'autre. Je retournai chez moi, et je n'osai encore me mettre au lit. Au lieu de le faire, je me mis  rvasser, comme le font ceux qui ont beaucoup de choses sur l'esprit. J'en tais presque  me demander si je me moquais bien de vous, si je ne m'tais pas trompe, et si, aprs tout, j'avais bien fait de me livrer  cette passion folle. J'en ai eu des moments comme cela. J'ai eu l'impression, au moins, de pouvoir m'examiner moi-mme, et de connatre  peu prs mon me. Cette rflexion me parat bonne. Le fait est que, le lendemain matin, je le vis, et que nous nous trouvions comme d'habitude, devisant et rvant. Il me sembla alors que Melchior n'avait eu pour moi ni piti ni indulgence. Il n'avait pas t aussi douc- dant. Il avait t dur. En gnral, il ne me parlait plus de vous, et moi-mme je ne lui en disais plus rien. Les jours suivants, nous restmes toujours dans la mme situation. A la fin, j'en eus un moment de chagrin, comme d'avoir mis ma tte en danger; je l'en blmai, et je me trouvai bien de n'tre pas la complice de ses actions. Au milieu de cet embarras, je me demandais ce qu'il aurait pu faire. - Quel parti aura-t-il pris? Pourrait-il avoir eu la barbarie de vous faire du mal? Je me promis de le lui demander et de lui faire de bien douces reproches. Il ne me fit jamais aucun reproche. Les mois s'coulrent. Il ne me demanda plus de nouvelles. J'en parlai, et il me rpondit que le voyage tait bien commenc, qu'il en avait vu le dbut, et que je devais tre bien contente de tout le bien qu

Je courus vers la porte et ouvris. C'tait Melchior. XXVI Je ne chercherai pas, Ludovic,  vous raconter ce que j'prouvai  la vue de cet homme. Aprs avoir parl du logement que j'avais lou et de la situation o vous et Melchior en tiez pour l'instant, nous prmes cong l'un de l'autre. Je retournai chez moi, et je n'osai encore me mettre au lit. Au lieu de le faire, je me mis  rvasser, comme le font ceux qui ont beaucoup de choses sur l'esprit. J'en tais presque  me demander si je me moquais bien de vous, si je ne m'tais pas trompe, et si, aprs tout, j'avais bien fait de me livrer  cette passion folle. J'en ai eu des moments comme cela. J'ai eu l'impression, au moins, de pouvoir m'examiner moi-mme, et de connatre  peu prs mon me. Cette rflexion me parat bonne. Le fait est que, le lendemain matin, je le vis, et que nous nous trouvions comme d'habitude, devisant et rvant. Il me sembla alors que Melchior n'avait eu pour moi ni piti ni indulgence. Au milieu de cet embarras, je me demandais ce qu'il aurait pu faire. - Quel parti aura-t-il pris? Pourrait-il avoir eu la barbarie de vous faire du mal? Je me promis de le lui demander et de lui faire de bien douces reproches. Il ne me fit jamais aucun reproche. Les mois s'coulrent. Il ne me demanda plus de nouvelles. groundtruth.region: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. 251 comme une exception parmi le commun des hommes, et que vous tiez ce qu'ils sont tous, perfides et trompeurs  l'occasion. Dans l'acte qui instituait le jeune avocat pour son hritier, ces divers voeux taient exprims dans la forme la plus simple et la plus touchante. Elle s'excusait d'avoir si peu  offrir, et priait qu'on lui tint compte de l'intention saps s'arrter  la valeur des choses. Chaque legs tait d'ailleurs appropri  la personne avec un soin dlicat qui y ajoutait un nouveau prix. Marguerite eut une dernire attention elle laissa son se-crtaire ouvert et plaa sur la tablette la pice qui rendait Ludovic matre de tout rgler chez elle et d'agir  son gr. Prs du testament tait l'anneau, ce triste et mystrieux em-blme. Ds le premier abord les yeux devaient se porter sur ces objets, et le jeune homme y reconnatrait quelles avaient t, au moment de quitter ce monde, la pense de la mou-rante et sa proccupation. Quand elle en eut fini avec la terre, Marguerite songea au ciel elle s'agenouilla devant le portrait de sa grand'mre et pria avec ferveur. Que fut cette prire? Sans doute un acte de contritipp et en mme temps un cri de dsespoir. Elle prit Dieu  tmoin, et, lui montrant l'tat de son me, invo-qua sa misricorde ayec un accent plor. Puis s'adressant  cette aeule qui avait si saintement vcu et si saintement fini,  sa mre moissonne avant le temps et qui, son mari mort, avait, elle aussi, manqu de courage, elle les conjura sans doute d'intercder pour elle et d'obtenir qu'elle ft admise  leurs cts, daps le sjour des mes pures ou purifies par le repentir. Elle leur demanda d'unir leurs prires  la sienne afin d'en augmenter l'effet et d'ob-tenir ce pardon qui descend d'en haut sur les coeurs humi-lis et sincres. Quand elle eut mis sa conscience en paix, autant que le permettait l'acte violent auquel elle tait rsolue, elle monta sur son lit, ajusta ses vtements de manire  ce que rien n'y pt amener du dsordre, s'tendit sur les coussins, et, s'emparant d'une petite fiole qui tait  sa porte, elle l'ap-procha de ses lvres. 1 Quelques minutes aprs , elle tait plonge dans un en-gourdissement profond.

Sans doute un acte de contrition et en mme temps un cri de dsespoir. Elle prit Dieu  tmoin, et, lui montrant l'tat de son me, invo-qua sa misricorde avec un accent plor. Puis s'adressant  cette aeule qui avait si saintement vcu et si saintement fini,  sa mre moissonne avant le temps et qui, son mari mort, avait, elle aussi, manqu de courage, elle les conjura sans doute d'intercder pour elle et d'obtenir qu'elle ft admise  leurs cts, dans le sjour des mes pures ou purifies par le repentir. Elle leur demanda d'unir leurs prires  la sienne afin d'en augmenter l'effet et d'ob-tenir ce pardon qui descend d'en haut sur les coeurs humi-lis et sincres. ocr.sentence: the other young man, this his father had received wrong.
ocr.region: 247 OF FRYER BACON. told the other young man, this his father had received wrong. He answered againe, that it was faire. At last there grew such foule words betweenc them, and their bloods were so heated, that they presently stabbed one the other with their daggers, and so fell downe dead. Fryer Bacon seeing them fall, ranne to them, but it was too late, for they were breathlesse ere he came. This made him to grieve exceedingly be iudging that they had received the cause of their deaths by this glasse, tooke the glasse in his hand, aud uttered words to this effect Wretched Bacon, wretched in thy knowledge, in thy understanding wretched for thy art hath beene the ruine of these two gentlemen. Had I been busied in those holy things, the which mine order tyes me to, I had not had that time that made this wicked glasse wicked I weU may cad it, that is the causer of so vde an act would it were sensible, then should it feele my wrath but being as it is, He ruin it for ruining of them and with that he broke his rare and wonderftdl glasse, whose Hke the whole world had not. In this grief of his, came there newes to him of the deaths of Vandermast and Fryer Bungey This did increase his griefe, and made him sorrowfull, that in three days he would not eate any thing but kept his chamber.

This made him to grieve exceedingly he iudging that they had received the cause of their deaths by this glasse, tooke the glasse in his hand, and uttered words to this effect Wretched Bacon, wretched in thy knowledge, in thy understanding wretched for thy art hath beene the ruine of these two gentlemen. Had I been busied in those holy things, the which mine order tyes me to, I had not had that time that made this wicked glasse wicked I well may call it, that is the causer of so vile an act would it were sensible, then should it feele my wrath but being as it is, Ile ruin it for ruining of them and with that he broke his rare and wonderfull glasse, whose like the whole world had not. In this grief of his, came there newes to him of the deaths of Vandermast and Fryer Bungey This did increase his griefe, and made him sorrowfull, that in three days he would not eate any thing but kept his chamber.

Then foorth came another Devill named Downesnest, and said, Sir, I have caused two olde women to fight so sore together, and to beat each other about the head, that their eyes flew out that was well done said the master DeviU, with much thanke thou shalt be weU rewarded for thy labour. Then foorth went Frier Rush freshly, and with a good courage, and said Sir, I am in a religious place, and I governe the priour and his covent as I wiU myselfe, and they have me in great love and favour for I doe them many great pleasures, and I have brought them faire wenches every man one when they lust, and divers times I have caused debate and strife to faU among them, and I have made them staves, and caused them to fight stifly together, and to breake each others heads, and their armes and legges, and yet wiU I doe more among them ere I depart out of the place, for I shall make so great debate and strife among them, and the one shaU flea the other, then they sbaU come and dweU with us in hell, and burne in perpetuaU fire without end. Then said the maister Devdl to Rush, if thou have done as thou hast said, thou hast done well thy part, and I pray thee be ddigent thy selfe about thy businesse, and stirre them to sin, and speciaUy to these three, that is to say, wrath, gluttony, and lechery, and briefely to make an end of thy enterprise, and slip it not and

The PEOPLE OF ENGLAND. 287 "Then Sir," said Rush, "I shall doe what thou hast appointed unto me, and the sooner the better. God help me, I will doe my endewour with all my heart and best endeavour, for this place of England, for as I say, it is a place of strife and contention, and I am well assured that there is none in all the realme, as I have said, that hath done more debate and strife to man and wife than I. Now, Sir, I shall goe to the west, and I will begin my enterprise. And so taking his leaue of the master Devll, he said, I pray God to helpe me to succeed. Then he went his way and commen-ced his enterprise, as he promised, he went about the west, and he did as he had purposed. He brought in an olde woman, who was well furnished with mony, and made her dwel with a young man in a parish called Chestfield, in the Countie of Kent, he put a great wrath and envy in the olde womans heart against her, that she durst not come to church or pray, but was sore in her mind. And so she kept at home, and prayed not and went not to church, but kept her bed all the weeke long and never would eat or drink; the younge man thought that she was in some frenzy, and so left her. He was a young man, and the olde womans servant, a young woman, he put in her heart the envy and wrath to see his master well to bed with his wi

What happened? The text is a 19th-century version of the 16th-century text that was transcribed and published by John Russell, as part of The Chronicles of Froissart. It is a translation of an account of the life and travels of the Frenchman Jean Froissart (1337 - 1410). The text is a collection of historical writings that covers the period from 1327 to 1405. Froissart's chronicles are a mixture of true historical material, fiction, and mythology. He includes many legends and fantastical stories, often exaggerated or embellished by the tale-teller. In his day, Froissart was a successful writer, but his tales have become outdated. Modern historians believe that they are mostly fictional and unreliable.

Now, Sir, I shall goe to the west, and I will begin my enterprise. And so taking his leaue of the master Devll, he said, I pray God to helpe me to succeed. Then he went his way and commen-ced his enterprise, as he promised, he went about the west, and he did as he had purposed. ocr.sentence: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE.
ocr.region: CE QU'ON PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE. 269 o cette scne se passait. Par le concours des circonstances, j'tais compromise  un point qu'aucune rparation n'tait possible, si ce n'est celle que pouvait m'offrir Melcbior. Son but tait atteint il m'avait mise  la discrtion de son hon-neur. Triste garantie ! et je le vis bien plus tard. Je succombai une barrire s'leva entre vous et moi je ne pouvais plus tre  vous, Ludovic. Les heures s'cou-laient il fallut prendre un parti. Encore quelques instants, et vous alliez venir chercher votre fiance impossible de vous attendre en vous voyant je serais tombe morte  vos pieds. Nous primes donc, Melchior et moi, nos dernires dis-positions. Au petit jour, et quand la porte fut ouverte, il quitta la maison. Un rendez-vous avait t fix, et je devais aller le rejoindre. Il passa sans tre aperu peut-tre le concierge tait-il son complice. Quant  moi, je restai pendant une heure encore abme dans mes regrets et mes remords. -Toutes vos bonts me revinrent alors  la mmoire, et je me trouvai bien ingrate, bien cruelle et en mme temps bien dchue. -Qu'ai liez-vous penser de moi? Hlas 1 quoi que vous pussiez en penser, la ralit dpasserait vos suppositions. J'tais une fille dshonore ! XXX - Pourtant, Ludovic, je vous crivis quelques mots, non pas tels que j'aurais voulu les crire, mais assez prcis pour que dsormais vous me regardassiez comme perdue pour vous. Puis j'enlevai de mon doigt l'anneau qui me venait de ma grand'mre et qui avait si mal prserv mon honneur. Je n'tais plus digne de le porter, quoi qu'il arrivt et de quel-que faon que tournassent les choses. Je rejoignis Melchior et le trouvai ivre de son bonheur. Moi-mme,  ce premier moment, j'prouvai ce vertige des sens qui n'est que la fausse monnaie de l'amour. Melchior

Il passa sans tre aperu peut-tre le concierge tait-il son complice. Quant  moi, je restai pendant une heure encore abme dans mes regrets et mes remords. Toutes vos bonts me revinrent alors  la mmoire, et je me trouvai bien ingrate, bien cruelle et en mme temps bien dchue. Qu'alliez-vous penser de moi ? XXX Pourtant, Ludovic, je vous crivis quelques mots, non pas tels que j'aurais voulu les crire, mais assez prcis pour que dsormais vous me regardassiez comme perdue pour vous. Puis j'enlevai de mon doigt l'anneau qui me venait de ma grand'mre et qui avait si mal prserv mon honneur. Je n'tais plus digne de le porter, quoi qu'il arrivt et de quel-que faon que tournassent les choses. Je rejoignis Melchior et le trouvai ivre de son bonheur. Moi-mme,  ce premier moment, j'prouvai ce vertige des sens qui n'est que la fausse monnaie de l'amour. Melchior

On sait  quel homme il avait af-faire, c'tait un casuiste en matire d'attributions il s'lana  la poursuite de l'intrus. -Monsieur! s'cria-t-il, Monsieur ! Ludovic tait dj loin. Mais le docteur y avait mis moins de zle, et ce fut sur lui que le concierge se rabattit. -O allez-vous, Monsieur ? lui dit-il en lui barrant le pas-sage. Le docteur et t embarrass de le dire. Il avait suivi son ami et ignorait chez qui ils allaient. -O je vais ? dit-il avec un peu d'impatience mais vous le voyez bien. -Comment, je le vois ? mais je vois que vous tombez sur mon escalier comme une bombe sans me dire seulement gare, ni me fournir un mot d'explication. Voil ce que je vois. -J'accompagne mon camarade, dit le docteur en essayant de s'ouvrir un chemin laissez-moi passer. -Votre camarade ? Il est aussi peu gn que vous ! -Voyons, finissons-en. La querelle s'chauffait, et l'austre concierge tait bien dcid  faire respecter ses consignes, dt-il compromettre l'intgrit de ses membres. Il avait pris la rampe  deux mains et s'arc-boutait de manire  ce qu'il ne restt point d'espace libre sur les degrs. A moins de violence, le pas-sage tait infranchissable, et le docteur n'osait pas pousser les choses si loin. Heureusement Ludovic se ravisa sans lui, l'affaire ne pouvait pas s'arranger il prit le parti de des-cendre.

Il s'tait vanoui. - Ah! c'est lui. Il est bien chang, mais on reconnat le masque, dit-on en regardant Ludovic. 193 - 281 paraissait sur le perron. Il tait de haute taille et d'une grande prestance. Son front tait svre et froid, son regard tait perant et scrutateur. On et dit un gnral ou un homme d'tat. ocr.sentence: foresee, was caused by the Germane coniurer Van-dermast, for he vowed a revenge for the disgrace that he had received.
ocr.region: 226 THE FAMOUS HISTORY did foresee, was caused by the Germane coniurer Van dermast, for he vowed a revenge for the disgrace that he had received. To execute the same, bee hyred a Walloon souldier, and gave him one hundred crownes to do the same, fifty beforehand, and fifty when hee had kdled him. Fryer Bacon, to save himselfe from this danger that was like to happen to him would alwayes wrhen that he read, hold a ball of brasse in his hand, and under that ball would hee set a bason of brasse, that if hee did chance to sleepe in bis reading, the fall of the ball out of his hand into the bason, might wake him. Being one day in his study in this manner, and asleepe, the Walloon souldier was got in to him, and had drawne his sword to kiU him but as hee was ready for to strike, downe fell the ball out of Fryer Bacon's hand, and waked him. Hee seeing the souldier stand there with a sworddrawne, asked him what hee was ? and wherefore hee came there in that manner ? The souldier boldly answered him thus I am a WaUoon, and a souldier, and more then this, a villaine I am come hither, because I was sent I was sent, because I was hyred I was hyred, because I durst do it the thing I should doe, is not done the thing to be done, is to kdl thee thus have you heard what I am and why I came. Fryer Bacon wondered at this man's resolution then asked hee of him, who set him on worke to bee a murderer ? Hee boldly told him, Vandermast the Germane coniurer Fryer Bacon then asked him what religion he was of ? He answered, of

the Religion of Catholique. The Fryer asked him, wherefore he came thither to him ? Fryer Bacon being thus awakened, took up his book, and reading till hee was wearied, slept again, the Walloon souldier having a hole in the ground to creep into, lay downe with his sword, and watched till hee saw him asleepe, and then the Walloon, leaped out of the hole, and taking a halfe of his sword, brake it in his hand, and then with the other halfe in the hand, came to him, saying, I am sent hither by Vander Mast the Germane, to kill you I must have answere of the book that you write, if not, I will kdl you. THE FAMOUS HISTORY OF FRYER BACON. 227 held him with the point of his sword, and being not able to get the answere of him, but hee would give it him, he drew his sword, and killed him." After which Fryer Bacon thus expresseth himself, "If the poeple had not beene so zealous for religion and for the name of Christ, they would not have done such things. They say, they were the poeple that did kill the kings and queens of England, for they were the enemies of the religion; but I am of another opinion, and therefore my book saith so much the contrary."

To execute the same, hee hyred a Walloon souldier, and gave him one hundred crownes to do the same, fifty beforehand, and fifty when hee had killed him. Fryer Bacon, to save himselfe from this danger that was like to happen to him would alwayes when that he read, hold a ball of brasse in his hand, and under that ball would hee set a bason of brasse, that if hee did chance to sleepe in his reading, the fall of the ball out of his hand into the bason, might wake him. Being one day in his study in this manner, and asleepe, the Walloon souldier was got in to him, and had drawne his sword to kill him but as hee was ready for to strike, downe fell the ball out of Fryer Bacon's hand, and waked him. Hee seeing the souldier stand there with a sword drawne, asked him what hee was ? and wherefore hee came there in that manner ? The souldier boldly answered him thus I am a Walloon, and a souldier, and more then this, a villaine I am come hither, because I was sent I was sent, because I was hyred I was hyred, because I durst do it the thing I should doe, is not done the thing to be done, is to kill thee thus have you heard what I am and why I came. Fryer Bacon wondered at this man's resolution then asked hee of him, who set him on worke to bee a murderer ? Hee boldly told him, Vandermast the Germane coniurer Fryer Bacon then asked him what religion he was of ? He answered, of

prediction.region:
the Religion of Catholique. The Fryer asked him, wherefore he came thither to him ? Hee told him, that because he had promised to kill him, if hee would not give him the answer of this booke, he was sent hither to doe it. Fryer Bacon being thus awakened, took up his book, and reading till hee was wearied, slept again, the Walloon souldier having a hole in the ground to creep into, lay downe with his sword, and watched till hee saw him asleepe, and then the Walloon, leaped out of the hole, and taking a halfe of his sword, brake it in his hand, and then with the other halfe in the hand, came to him, saying, I am sent hither by Vander Mast the Germane, to kill you I must have answere of the book that you write, if not, I will kdl you. If you are not willing to give me that answere, I must kill you for it. Then hee|\,|t
THE FAMOUS HISTORY OF FRYER BACON. 227 held him with the point of his sword, and being not able to get the answere of him, but hee would give it him, he drew his sword, and killed him." After which Fryer Bacon thus expresseth himself, "If the poeple had not beene so zealous for religion and for the name of Christ, they would not have done such things. They say, they were the poeple that did kill the kings and queens of England, for they were the enemies of the religion; but I am of another opinion, and therefore my book saith so much the contrary."

The Fryer having thus delivered his opinion, in this book, about Vandermast, to whatsoever hee was; the poeple of England took it in great indignation against him, and with great fury of mind, and were minded to have torn

Fryer Bacon being thus awakened, took up his book, and reading till hee was wearied, slept again, the Walloon souldier having a hole in the ground to creep into, lay downe with his sword, and watched till hee saw him asleepe, and then the Walloon, leaped out of the hole, and taking a halfe of his sword, brake it in his hand, and then with the other halfe in the hand, came to him, saying, I am sent hither by Vander Mast the Germane, to kill you I must have answere of the book that you write, if not, I will kdl you. If you are not willing to give me that answere, I must kill you for it. Then hee|\,|t
THE FAMOUS HISTORY OF FRYER BACON. 227 held him with the point of his sword, and being not able to get the answere of him, but hee would give it him, he drew his sword, and killed him." After which Fryer Bacon thus expresseth himself, "If the poeple had not beene so zealous for religion and for the name of Christ, they would not have done such things. ocr.sentence: LES TLPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 9 III LA FERME DE BEAUSJOUR L A feuille  la main, le sergent, debout devant l'abri du colonel, faisait la rpartition des postes.
ocr.region: LES TLPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 9 III LA FERME DE BEAUSJOUR L A feuille  la main, le sergent, debout devant l'abri du colonel, faisait la rpartition des postes. - Duruy, dit-il, tu vas monter avec tes hommes au secteur I, tu longeras un peu la route jusqu'aux boyaux B 1 et B 2, au tournant du ruisseau, ils sont perpendiculaires  la Grande Transversale, aprs quoi tu monteras tout droit jus-qu'au poste du commandant. Ne t'amuse pas en chemin, car  peu prs cinq cents mtres avant d'arriver, il voltige des bom-bes!. Legrand, tu prends le secteur H, dangereux pour les marmites, surtout au Bois Equerre tu suivras le boyau central jusqu'au boyau Boscary, o tu trouveras le poste de son com-mandant. Attention vous autres, baissez la tte, les balles tra-versent la route! Je garde deux hommes avec moi au poste du colonel,  da borne 16. La nuit tait venne, pas de lune, une obscurit complte rgnait sur les tranches, et sauf les coups de fusils espacs, partant des premires lignes, la soire tait calme. Les fuses dans le ciel irradiaient par moments l'horizon de leur courbe gracieuse, inondant les parapets d'une lueur blafarde. L'quipe se spara en deux. Puis,  la file, les nouveaux venus longrent la route le plus prs possible du remblai pour viter les balles perdues qui froufroutaient avec un bruit de soie, allant frapper les troncs d'arbres de l'autre ct du ruis-seau. - Pour une belle nuit, c'est une beMe nuit, remarqua R-gnier, un combat de ngres sous un tunnel et  chaque fuse il gouaillait Ah! la belle bleue! - Allez, activez le mouvement, lana Legrand impatient, en laissant derrire lui Duruy qui entrait dans son boyau, nous avons encore un bout de chemin! Sans se dtourner il poursuivit sa marche  ttons, cher-chant  ehaque trou la pancarte indicatrice.

prediction.region: 11. Corrections of the text. Correct the text: "LES TLPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 9 III LA FERME DE BEAUSJOUR La route A 111  droite aboutissait  la grande route  gauche. Un arbre avait t taill en porte- drapeau. Ce bois avait servi de censeur au commandement et aux pelotons en marche. Il tait plant dans la route par un dtachement de soldats en garde. Toutes les deux heures, la lumire d'un rflecteur l'clairait. Le lieutenant et ses hommes marchaient. En arrivant sur ce trononnement, ils s'arrtrent pour s'assurer que le drapeau flottait. Le lieutenant dit alors  Duruy : - On ne te quitte pas, mon ami, tu vas le garder tout  ton aise. - N'importe, rpondit-il, le cesse-feu n'a pas sonn et nous en sommes peut-tre l-bas  des fuses de joyeux retranchs,  des salves d'amis. - Allons! fit le lieutenant, les premiers drapeaux sont venus. C'est le commandement d'infanterie qui vous emmne, et il vous laisse  notre garde jusqu' ce que le drapeau fasse retraite. Vous y voil. - Merci, monsieur, je vous suis trs reconnaissant. - Tire-moi mon couteau, dit  Legrand le caporal du deuxime peloton. - J'ai ma rapire, fit Legrand, on s'en dfendra. Et il se baissait pour prendre la rapire qui pendait  son ct, mais le caporal, qui s'tait retourn, s'lana sur lui. Il frappa sa baonnette sur la tte. La faible rsistance du caporal ne lui tait pas venue de compassion pour son camarade, mais d'une lenteur d'me. L'air tait charg de cris et de pleurs. Il s'excusait, en levant ses mains comme des gens qui disent des prires. Et il continuait. - L'ami! l'ami! l'ami! fit un tiers. - Je ne veux pas! dit Legrand qui se redressait. Il allait chercher son pistolet quand le lieutenant d'infanterie l'arrta. - Attendez, fit

Puis,  la file, les nouveaux venus longrent la route le plus prs possible du remblai pour viter les balles perdues qui froufroutaient avec un bruit de soie, allant frapper les troncs d'arbres de l'autre ct du ruis-seau. - Pour une belle nuit, c'est une beMe nuit, remarqua R-gnier, un combat de ngres sous un tunnel et  chaque fuse il gouaillait Ah! la belle bleue! - Allez, activez le mouvement, lana Legrand impatient, en laissant derrire lui Duruy qui entrait dans son boyau, nous avons encore un bout de chemin! Sans se dtourner il poursuivit sa marche  ttons, cher-chant  ehaque trou la pancarte indicatrice.

La nuit tait venne, pas de lune, une obscurit complte rgnait sur les tranches, et sauf les coups de fusils espacs, partant des premires lignes, la soire tait calme. Les fuses dans le ciel irradiaient par moments l'horizon de leur courbe gracieuse, inondant les parapets d'une lueur blafarde. L'quipe se spara en deux. Puis,  la file, les nouveaux venus longrent la route le plus prs possible du remblai pour viter les balles perdues qui froufroutaient avec un bruit de soie, allant frapper les troncs d'arbres de l'autre ct du ruis-seau. - Pour une belle nuit, c'est une beMe nuit, remarqua R-gnier, un combat de ngres sous un tunnel et  chaque fuse il gouaillait Ah! la belle bleue! - Allez, activez le mouvement, lana Legrand impatient, en laissant derrire lui Duruy qui entrait dans son boyau, nous avons encore un bout de chemin! Sans se dtourner il poursuivit sa marche  ttons, cher-chant  ehaque trou la pancarte indicatrice.

Toutes les deux heures, la lumire d'un rflecteur l'clairait. Le lieutenant et ses hommes marchaient. En arrivant sur ce trononnement, ils s'arrtrent pour s'assurer que le drapeau flottait. Le lieutenant dit alors  Duruy : - On ne te quitte pas, mon ami, tu vas le garder tout  ton aise. - N'importe, rpondit-il, le cesse-feu n'a pas sonn et nous en sommes peut-tre l-bas  des fuses de joyeux retranchs,  des salves d'amis. - Allons! fit le lieutenant, les premiers drapeaux sont venus. C'est le commandement d'infanterie qui vous emmne, et il vous laisse  notre garde jusqu' ce que le drapeau fasse retraite. Vous y voil. - Merci, monsieur, je vous suis trs reconnaissant. - Tire-moi mon couteau, dit  Legrand le caporal du deuxime peloton. - J'ai ma rapire, fit Legrand, on s'en dfendra. Et il se baissait pour prendre la rapire qui pendait  son ct, mais le caporal, qui s'tait retourn, s'lana sur lui. Il frappa sa baonnette sur la tte. La faible rsistance du caporal ne lui tait pas venue de compassion pour son camarade, mais d'une lenteur d'me. L'air tait charg de cris et de pleurs. Il s'excusait, en levant ses mains comme des gens qui disent des prires. Et il continuait. - L'ami! l'ami! l'ami! fit un tiers. - Je ne veux pas! dit Legrand qui se redressait. ocr.sentence: CE PEUT VOIR DANS UNE RUE.
ocr.region: CE qu'on PEUT VOIR DANS UNE rue. 257, j'obis, tant il y avait en moi de confusion et de trouble. Il faut si. peu de chose pour arrter une confidence sur les lvres, surtout lorsqu'il s'agit de s'accuser d'un tort et de se mettre  la merci d'autrui ! On s'empare alors du premier prtexte, le plus futile, le plus spcieux on recule, on ajourne, et, dans ces ajournements mmes, -on puise des mo-tifs pour s'abstenir. C'est ce qui m'arriva, Ludovic. Avant- de vous revoir, j'tais rsolue  tout vous dire, et quand je vous revis la confiance me manqua. Il n'y eut l-dedans ni raisonnement, ni calcul mais une force imprieuse et presque indpen-dante de ma volont. Puis je me payais de dfaites. Pourquoi troubler votre scurit et veiller vos soupons? La chose en valait-elle la peine? Cet homme, en venant chez moi, avait obi  un caprice probablement il n'y reviendrait plus. Et s'il revenait, quoi de plus ais que de le remettre  sa place et de faire justice de ses airs cavaliers ? tait-il besoin d'aide pour cela et ne valait-il pas mieux procder sans bruit, sans clat, .comme une femme peut et doit le faire, que de mettre deux hommes en prsence et jusqu'aux prises pour un si lger motif? Voil  quelles impressions je cdai sans m'en rendre bien compte, ni pntrer trop avant dans mon coeur Peut-tre, hlas ! en interrogeant mieux ce coeur, aurais-je trouv le dernier mot de ces rticences. La suite ne l'a que trop prouv j'tais dj touche, j'entrais dans cette srie de faiblesses qui m'ont perdue. C'est ici que j'ai besoin de votre pardon, Ludovic, d'un pardon absolu et gnreux. Point d'excuse possible, rien qui puisse pallier ce commen-cement de trahison. Vous aviez t pour moi le meilleur, le plus dvou et le plus fidle des amis vous n'aviez qu'une pense, mon bonheur qu'un but, notre union. Jamais, c'est une justice que je me plais  vous rendre, aucun chagrin ne m'est venu de vous si j'exprimais un dsir, vous vous em-pressiez de le satisfaire si j'avais un ennui, vous vous offriez - le partager. Vous tiez de ces loyaux compagnons qu'une femme est trop heureuse de rencontrer dans sa vie, qui l'as-sistent dans les bons et les mauvais jours et se donnent sans rserve comme sans calcul. Je voyais tout cela, je le sentais et ne mconnaissais point-vos mrites. Lui, au contraire, qu'tait-il et quel fonds pouvais-je -

Le dsir que vous avez d'en tre quitte, la vive et juste indignation dont vous vous tes fait l'cho, l'aveu d'un pass d'infidlit que j'ai t pour ainsi dire force d'admettre, tout me le prouve et me fait connatre mon erreur. Pourquoi me laisse-tu devoir en taire davantage? pourquoi me refuses-tu d'en dire plus? A-t-il t moins coupable que je le croyais? ou n'y avait-il pas dans ses manuvres, et peut-tre mme dans ses sentiments, une grande navet qui ne voulait pas laisser paratre la moindre liaison et qui s'tait crue, -par une illusion toute fminine, dans l'impression qu'elle faisait, et dans une indiscrtion, d'aprs laquelle l'attention et le plaisir venaient  sa place et  sa place seule. Pourquoi, Ludovic, pourquoi refuses-tu d'en dire davantage et laisse-t-il que la preuve de tout cela se fasse par moi seule. ocr.region: CE qu'on PEUT VOIR DANS UNE rue. 257, j'obis, tant il y avait en moi de confusion et de trouble. Il faut si. peu de chose pour arrter une confidence sur les lvres, surtout lorsqu'il s'agit de s'accuser d'un tort et de se mettre  la merci d'autrui ! On s'empare alors du premier prtexte, le plus futile, le plus spcieux on recule, on ajourne, et, dans ces ajournements mmes, -on puise des mo-tifs pour s'abstenir. C'est ce qui m'arriva, Ludovic. Avant- de vous revoir, j'tais rsolue  tout vous dire, et quand je vous revis la confiance me manqua. Il n'y eut l-dedans ni raisonnement, ni calcul mais une force imprieuse et presque indpen-dante de ma volont. Puis je me payais de dfaites. Pourquoi troubler votre scurit et veiller vos soupons? La chose en valait-elle la peine? Cet homme, en venant chez moi, avait obi  un caprice probablement il n'y reviendrait plus. Et s'il revenait, quoi de plus ais que de le remettre  sa place et de faire justice de ses airs cavaliers ? tait-il besoin d'aide pour cela et ne valait-il pas mieux procder sans bruit, sans clat, .comme une femme peut et doit le faire, que de mettre deux hommes en prsence et jusqu'aux prises pour un si lger motif? Voil  quelles impressions je cdai sans m'en rendre bien compte, ni pntrer trop avant dans mon coeur Peut-tre, hlas ! en interrogeant mieux ce coeur, aurais-je trouv le dernier mot de ces rticences. La suite ne l'a que trop prouv j'tais dj touche, j'entrais dans cette srie de faiblesses qui m'ont perdue. C'est ici que j'ai besoin de votre pardon, Ludovic, d'un pardon absolu et gnreux. Point d'excuse possible, rien qui puisse pallier ce commen-cement de trahison. Vous aviez t pour moi le meilleur, le plus dvou et le plus fidle des amis vous n'aviez qu'une pense, mon bonheur qu'un but, notre union. Jamais, c'est une justice que je me plais  vous rendre, aucun chagrin ne m'est venu de vous si j'exprimais un dsir, vous vous em-pressiez de le satisfaire si j'avais un ennui, vous vous offriez - le partager. Vous tiez de ces loyaux compagnons qu'une femme est trop heureuse de rencontrer dans sa vie, qui l'as-sistent dans les bons et les mauvais jours et se donnent sans rserve comme sans calcul. Je voyais tout cela, je le sentais et ne mconnaissais point-vos mrites. Lui, au contraire, qu'tait-il et quel fonds pouvais-je -

ocr.region: LES TLPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 11 - Dans deux heures. O est notre poste?  'j,' '.tJit,d - J'en sais rien. - ~ H - Merci! Et sans se rebuter il continua, s'adressant  des poilus qui tiraillaient quelques cartouches. - C'est les tlphonistes. - Ah, les embusqus! chuchotrent les hommes. - Oui, embusqus de premire ligne comme vous autres, rpondit Rgnier rageusement, et il continua  questionner - Le poste tlphonique? - Taisez-vous, souffla un sergent, nous sommes  vingt mtres des Boches! Soudain une tte surgit d'un trou et un bras lui lit signe d'approcher. - C'est nous, fit Rgnier, o est le poste? - Y en a pas, rpondit une voix, on est tasss dans un gourbi! Couch presque  plat ventre, Rgnier se raunJa dans l'exca-vation. - C'est maigre, miladious! murmura-t-il, enQn.! Accroupi, ramass sur lui-mme, 11 tablit tant bien que mal sa communication. - Allo! caporal Legrand, c'est vous?. C'est Rgnier qui est  l'appareil. Bon. a marche. Vous dites?. Ah! oui, je crois que le climat n'est pas sain, vu l'humidit. J'ai peur de prendre racine. Je me sens dj des fourmis dans les jambes. Al-lons, bonne nuit, caporal. - Dites donc, vous n'tes pas l pour faire la causette, fit brusquement un adjudant, fermez a une fois pour toutes. Le mieux pour lui tait de ne pas rpliquer, car il se sentait dans une atmosphre hostile. Les deux soldats qui partaient, sans plus tarder, mirent leuss sacs, s'loignrent sur une poigne de main. - Ce n'est pas confortable l dedans, soupira le Mridional assis en tailleur. j'ai des crampes dans tes genoux, mais ce qui me console, c'est que je ne paie pas mon loyer! La nuit s'annonait assez tranquille, fatigus par les atta. ques des jours prcdents, les Allemands paraissaient plutt inquiets qu'agressifs. Insensible et bris de fatigue. Buchard s'tait endormi. Seul Rgnier veillait et comme il n'avait personne  qui parler, 11 s'lait mis  manger un morceau de singe et vidait ce qui lql restait de pinard.

Soudain une tte surgit d'un trou et un bras lui fit signe d'approcher. -C'est nous, fit Rgnier, o est le poste? -Y en a pas, rpondit une voix, on est tasss dans un gourbi! Couch presque  plat ventre, Rgnier se faufila dans l'exca-vation. -C'est maigre, miladious! murmura-t-il, enfin...! Accroupi, ramass sur lui-mme, il tablit tant bien que mal sa communication. -Allo! caporal Legrand, c'est vous?... C'est Rgnier qui est  l'appareil... Bon... a marche... Vous dites?... Ah! oui, je crois que le climat n'est pas sain, vu l'humidit. J'ai peur de prendre racine. Je me sens dj des fourmis dans les jambes... Al-lons, bonne nuit, caporal. -Dites donc, vous n'tes pas l pour faire la causette, fit brusquement un adjudant, fermez a une fois pour toutes. Le mieux pour lui tait de ne pas rpliquer, car il se sentait dans une atmosphre hostile. Les deux soldats qui partaient, sans plus tarder, mirent leurs sacs, s'loignrent sur une poigne de main. -Ce n'est pas confortable l dedans, soupira le Mridional assis en tailleur, j'ai des crampes dans les genoux, mais ce qui me console, c'est que je ne paie pas mon loyer! La nuit s'annonait assez tranquille, fatigus par les atta-ques des jours prcdents, les Allemands paraissaient plutt inquiets qu'agressifs. Insensible et bris de fatigue. Buchard s'tait endormi. Seul Rgnier veillait et comme il n'avait personne  qui parler, il s'tait mis  manger un morceau de singe et vidait ce qui lui restait de pinard.

ocr.region: LES TLPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 11 - Dans deux heures. O est notre poste?  'j,' '.tJit,d - J'en sais rien. - ~ H - Merci! Et sans se rebuter il continua, s'adressant  des poilus qui tiraillaient quelques cartouches. - C'est les tlphonistes. - Ah, les embusqus! chuchotrent les hommes. - Oui, embusqus de premire ligne comme vous autres, rpondit Rgnier rageusement, et il continua  questionner - Le poste tlphonique? - Taisez-vous, souffla un sergent, nous sommes  vingt mtres des Boches! Soudain une tte surgit d'un trou et un bras lui lit signe d'approcher. - C'est nous, fit Rgnier, o est le poste? - Y en a pas, rpondit une voix, on est tasss dans un gourbi! Couch presque  plat ventre, Rgnier se raunJa dans l'exca-vation. - C'est maigre, miladious! murmura-t-il, enQn.! Accroupi, ramass sur lui-mme, 11 tablit tant bien que mal sa communication. - Allo! caporal Legrand, c'est vous?. C'est Rgnier qui est  l'appareil. Bon. a marche. Vous dites?. Ah! oui, je crois que le climat n'est pas sain, vu l'humidit. J'ai peur de prendre racine. Je me sens dj des fourmis dans les jambes. Al-lons, bonne nuit, caporal. - Dites donc, vous n'tes pas l pour faire la causette, fit brusquement un adjudant, fermez a une fois pour toutes. Le mieux pour lui tait de ne pas rpliquer, car il se sentait dans une atmosphre hostile. Les deux soldats qui partaient, sans plus tarder, mirent leuss sacs, s'loignrent sur une poigne de main. - Ce n'est pas confortable l dedans, soupira le Mridional assis en tailleur. j'ai des crampes dans tes genoux, mais ce qui me console, c'est que je ne paie pas mon loyer! La nuit s'annonait assez tranquille, fatigus par les atta. ques des jours prcdents, les Allemands paraissaient plutt inquiets qu'agressifs. Insensible et bris de fatigue. Buchard s'tait endormi. Seul Rgnier veillait et comme il n'avait personne  qui parler, 11 s'lait mis  manger un morceau de singe et vidait ce qui lql restait de pinard.

ocr.sentence: C'est Rgnier qui est  l'appareil...
ocr.region: LES TLPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 11 - Dans deux heures. O est notre poste?  'j,' '.tJit,d - J'en sais rien. - ~ H - Merci! Et sans se rebuter il continua, s'adressant  des poilus qui tiraillaient quelques cartouches. - C'est les tlphonistes. - Ah, les embusqus! chuchotrent les hommes. - Oui, embusqus de premire ligne comme vous autres, rpondit Rgnier rageusement, et il continua  questionner - Le poste tlphonique? - Taisez-vous, souffla un sergent, nous sommes  vingt mtres des Boches! Soudain une tte surgit d'un trou et un bras lui lit signe d'approcher. - C'est nous, fit Rgnier, o est le poste? - Y en a pas, rpondit une voix, on est tasss dans un gourbi! Couch presque  plat ventre, Rgnier se raunJa dans l'exca-vation. - C'est maigre, miladious! murmura-t-il, enQn.! Accroupi, ramass sur lui-mme, 11 tablit tant bien que mal sa communication. - Allo! caporal Legrand, c'est vous?. C'est Rgnier qui est  l'appareil. Bon. a marche. Vous dites?. Ah! oui, je crois que le climat n'est pas sain, vu l'humidit. J'ai peur de prendre racine. Je me sens dj des fourmis dans les jambes. Al-lons, bonne nuit, caporal. - Dites donc, vous n'tes pas l pour faire la causette, fit brusquement un adjudant, fermez a une fois pour toutes. Le mieux pour lui tait de ne pas rpliquer, car il se sentait dans une atmosphre hostile. Les deux soldats qui partaient, sans plus tarder, mirent leuss sacs, s'loignrent sur une poigne de main. - Ce n'est pas confortable l dedans, soupira le Mridional assis en tailleur. j'ai des crampes dans tes genoux, mais ce qui me console, c'est que je ne paie pas mon loyer! La nuit s'annonait assez tranquille, fatigus par les atta. ques des jours prcdents, les Allemands paraissaient plutt inquiets qu'agressifs. Insensible et bris de fatigue. Buchard s'tait endormi. Seul Rgnier veillait et comme il n'avait personne  qui parler, 11 s'lait mis  manger un morceau de singe et vidait ce qui lql restait de pinard.

ocr.sentence: J'ai peur de prendre racine.
ocr.region: LES TLPHONISTES DANS LA BATAILLE 11 - Dans deux heures. O est notre poste?  'j,' '.tJit,d - J'en sais rien. - ~ H - Merci! Et sans se rebuter il continua, s'adressant  des poilus qui tiraillaient quelques cartouches. - C'est les tlphonistes. - Ah, les embusqus! chuchotrent les hommes. - Oui, embusqus de premire ligne comme vous autres, rpondit Rgnier rageusement, et il continua  questionner - Le poste tlphonique? - Taisez-vous, souffla un sergent, nous sommes  vingt mtres des Boches! Soudain une tte surgit d'un trou et un bras lui lit signe d'approcher. - C'est nous, fit Rgnier, o est le poste? - Y en a pas, rpondit une voix, on est tasss dans un gourbi! Couch presque  plat ventre, Rgnier se raunJa dans l'exca-vation. - C'est maigre, miladious! murmura-t-il, enQn.! Accroupi, ramass sur lui-mme, 11 tablit tant bien que mal sa communication. - Allo! caporal Legrand, c'est vous?. C'est Rgnier qui est  l'appareil. Bon. a marche. Vous dites?. Ah! oui, je crois que le climat n'est pas sain, vu l'humidit. J'ai peur de prendre racine. Je me sens dj des fourmis dans les jambes. Al-lons, bonne nuit, caporal. - Dites donc, vous n'tes pas l pour faire la causette, fit brusquement un adjudant, fermez a une fois pour toutes. Le mieux pour lui tait de ne pas rpliquer, car il se sentait dans une atmosphre hostile. Les deux soldats qui partaient, sans plus tarder, mirent leuss sacs, s'loignrent sur une poigne de main. - Ce n'est pas confortable l dedans, soupira le Mridional assis en tailleur. j'ai des crampes dans tes genoux, mais ce qui me console, c'est que je ne paie pas mon loyer! La nuit s'annonait assez tranquille, fatigus par les atta. ques des jours prcdents, les Allemands paraissaient plutt inquiets qu'agressifs. Insensible et bris de fatigue. Buchard s'tait endormi. Seul Rgnier veillait et comme il n'avait personne  qui parler, 11 s'lait mis  manger un morceau de singe et vidait ce qui lql restait de pinard.

Sans s'en douter, douard avait fait le tour du parc au lieu d'aller tout droit par l'alle du milieu, il avait tourn sur lui-mme et tait revenu  son point de dpart. C'tait bien l la porte du jardin. Il n'tait que neuf heures. La cloche continuait  sonner. Sans doute on s'tait aperu de son absence. Ce second coup de -cloche tait pour l'appeler. Encore un effort et ses ennemis vont s'arrter, bien sr il n'oseront pas le poursuivre si prs de la maison. En tout cas, il y arrivera le premier ! Le petit Edouard se trompait. La poursuite continuait. Mais douard tait rentr dans le jardin. Toute sa famille tait l qui l'appelait, qui le cherchait. Son pre tait sur la plate-forme du perron. Les domestiques effars couraient partout avec des lanternes. Chacun criait douard, douard! La voix de sa soeur venait jusqu' lui. Papa ! papa ! s'cria douard, cher papa ! je suis l ! Et le petit douard tombait  moiti mort de peur dans les bras de son pre. Mais il n'arrivait pas seul. Les voleurs, les gendarmes, tous ses ennemis, tous ses perscuteurs, anims sans doute, eux aussi, par leur course, avaient franchi la porte du jardin et faisaient effrontment irruption dans le salon en sonnant une fanfare clatante. Le croirait-on? mais la vrit nous oblige  le confesser la troupe des fantmes devant laquelle avait fui l'intrpide douard se composait d'un seul malfaiteur!. son petit ne, qui, en se trouvant tout  coup au milieu des lumires du salon, avait cru devoir clbrer son entre par le plus beau braiement qui ft jamais sorti de son gosier.

Il n'tait que neuf heures. La cloche continuait  sonner. Sans doute on s'tait aperu de son absence. Ce second coup de -cloche tait pour l'appeler. Encore un effort et ses ennemis vont s'arrter, bien sr il n'oseront pas le poursuivre si prs de la maison. En tout cas, il y arrivera le premier ! Le petit Edouard se trompait. La poursuite continuait. Mais douard tait rentr dans le jardin. Toute sa famille tait l qui l'appelait, qui le cherchait. Son pre tait sur la plate-forme du perron. Les domestiques effars couraient partout avec des lanternes. Chacun criait douard, douard! La voix de sa soeur venait jusqu' lui. Papa ! papa ! s'cria douard, cher papa ! je suis l ! Et le petit douard tombait  moiti mort de peur dans les bras de son pre. Mais il n'arrivait pas seul. Les voleurs, les gendarmes, tous ses ennemis, tous ses perscuteurs, anims sans doute, eux aussi, par leur course, avaient franchi la porte du jardin et faisaient effrontment irruption dans le salon en sonnant une fanfare clatante. Le croirait-on? mais la vrit nous oblige  le confesser la troupe des fantmes devant laquelle avait fui l'intrpide douard se composait d'un seul malfaiteur!. son petit ne, qui, en se trouvant tout  coup au milieu des lumires du salon, avait cru devoir clbrer son entre par le plus beau braiement qui ft jamais sorti de son gosier.

Sans s'en douter, douard avait fait le tour du parc au lieu d'aller tout droit par l'alle du milieu, il avait tourn sur lui-mme et tait revenu  son point de dpart. C'tait bien l la porte du jardin. Il n'tait que neuf heures. La cloche continuait  sonner. Sans doute on s'tait aperu de son absence. Ce second coup de -cloche tait pour l'appeler. Encore un effort et ses ennemis vont s'arrter, bien sr il n'oseront pas le poursuivre si prs de la maison. En tout cas, il y arrivera le premier ! Le petit Edouard se trompait. La poursuite continuait. Mais douard tait rentr dans le jardin. Toute sa famille tait l qui l'appelait, qui le cherchait. Son pre tait sur la plate-forme du perron. Les domestiques effars couraient partout avec des lanternes. Chacun criait douard, douard! La voix de sa soeur venait jusqu' lui. Papa ! papa ! s'cria douard, cher papa ! je suis l ! Et le petit douard tombait  moiti mort de peur dans les bras de son pre. Mais il n'arrivait pas seul. Les voleurs, les gendarmes, tous ses ennemis, tous ses perscuteurs, anims sans doute, eux aussi, par leur course, avaient franchi la porte du jardin et faisaient effrontment irruption dans le salon en sonnant une fanfare clatante. Le croirait-on? mais la vrit nous oblige  le confesser la troupe des fantmes devant laquelle avait fui l'intrpide douard se composait d'un seul malfaiteur!. son petit ne, qui, en se trouvant tout  coup au milieu des lumires du salon, avait cru devoir clbrer son entre par le plus beau braiement qui ft jamais sorti de son gosier.

103. The Manciple's Tale
Certainly this tale is meant to be a reproof of the covetous, who are called "panders," or mammon. In the same manner as in the "Pardoner's Tale," "Giles of Rome," etc., the tale is told by a Manciple, in this case a Benedictine monk, who, to increase the value of his goods, has sold himself as a slave to a money-lender or Jew. It has been generally considered a satire on the Church; in which opinion

That will wee not, said they all. Miles thought now to have some sport with them, which hee had, and therefore plaid lustily on his tabor and pipe so soone as they heard him play against their wills they fell a dauncing, and that after such a laborious manner, that they quickly wearied themselves for they had all that while the bagges of money in their hands. Yet had Fryer Bacon not revenge enough of them, but bid his man Miles leave them some larger measure as hee thought fitting, which Miles did. Miles straight ledde them out of the house into the fields, they followed him, dauncing after a wilde anticke man-ner then led hee them over a broad dike full of water, and they followed him still, but not so good a way as he went for he went over the bridge, but they by reason of their dauncing, could not keepe the bridge, but fell off, and dauncing through the water then led hee them through a way where a horse might very well have been up to the belly they followed him, and were so durtie, as though they had wallowed in the myre like swine sometime gave hee them rest onely to laugh at them then were they so sleepie when hee did not play, that they fell to the ground. Then on a sudden would hee play againe, and make them start up and follow him. Thus kept hee them the better part of the night. At

Certainly this tale is meant to be a reproof of the covetous, who are called "panders," or mammon. It has been generally considered a satire on the Church; in which opinion

B. - "Of Fryer Bacon. 223." - "Was Fryer Bacon not revenge enough of them, but bid his man Mdes leave them some larger measure, as hee thought fitting, which Mdes did. Mdes straight led them out of the house into the fields, they followed him, dauncing after a wilde anticke manner, they went, not so good a way as he went, for hee went over the bridge, but they by reason of their dauncing, could not keep the bridge, but fell off, and dauncing through the water then, led bee them through a way where a horse might very well have been up to the neck they followed him, and were so dull, as though they had wallowed in the mire, sometimes gave hee them rest, only to laugh at them. Then on a sudden would hee play again, and make them start up and follow him. Thus kept hee them the better part of the night. At three of the clock in the morning Mdes led them out of the field, and brought them againe into their houses." - "M. F. P." - "125." B.
103. The Manciple's Tale
Certainly this tale is meant to be a reproof of the covetous, who are called "panders," or mammon. In the same manner as in the "Pardoner's Tale," "Giles of Rome," etc., the tale is told by a Manciple, in this case a Benedictine monk, who, to increase the value of his goods, has sold himself as a slave to a money-lender or Jew. It has been generally considered a satire on the Church; in which opinion

ocr.sentence: he said to Rush, thou lewd fellow, what hast thou done to this waggon that I am thus arayed therein ?
ocr.region: 277 OF FRIER RUSH. then he said to Rush, thou lew d fellow, what bast thou done to this waggon that I am thus arayed therein ? Rush answered and said sir, I have done nothing but as you commanded me. That is not, said the Priour, for I commaunded thee to take greace and grease but the wheeles and the axeltrees, and thou hast taken tarre and annointed it all over, both within and without. Why hast thou done so ? Sir said Rush, I understoode you bad me doe so. And when the Priour sawe there was no other remedie, he commanded his servants to makeready another waggon, and in the meane season, the Priour went into his chamber, and put on another babite, and came againe and mounted into the waggon and went their way, and so long they rode, that they came to their iourneyes end. And when they were alighted at their lodging, the Priour caUed for his supper, and anon every thing was made ready, and the good man of the house and the Priour sate downe to supper together, and made good cheere and then the Priour called for wine of the best, and anon he had his commandement. And when the good man of the house and the Priour had supped, Rush and bis fellowes sate downe to the rever sions that their maisters bad left, but they had no wine wherefore Rush was very sad, and ever he mused by what policie he might get some wine. And anon he called the wife of the house and said Mistresse, I pray you fill a pottle of wine for me and my fellowes, and so shee did and when that was gone, they caUed for another and then they called for the third, and so ended their
